ygData.subject: Re: Crossover doing anything in HyperNEAT and PNEAT?
ygData.msgSnippet: Well yes this is exactly what it has to be. Note that randomChoice has to be random every time you refer to it. If it is not random (i.e. outside the big loop)

Well yes this is exactly what it has to be. Note that randomChoice has 
to =
be random every time you refer to it. If it is not random (i.e. 
outside th=
e big loop) then you choose links from either parent. But if 
it is inside =
the loop, then you choose a gene randomly from either 
parent. Check this o=
ut and you will have a clearer picture if there is 
a bug or not. 
But the =
cloning issue is a deeper one. In this case you must ensure 
that individua=
ls should not mate with themselves or such ones that 
have zero compatibili=
ty distance. Or at least try a few hundred times 
to find a different mate =
:) Hey, I say this to all users. Don't use 
rand(), fuck that, use the Mers=
enne Twister instead. I noticed that in 
enhances performance! 

Peter

---=
 In neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune <jclune@...> wrote:
>
> Hi Petar-
> 
>=
 Thanks for the reply. I do not have a (non-HyperNEAT) NEAT package 
around=
.
> Can you let me know if your NEAT implementation is different than 
what=
 I
> report below?
> 
> I am using Jason's HyperNEAT 2.5 package available =
here:
> 
> http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/software.html
> 
> If you download the p=
ackage, the key file is:
> HyperNEAT/NEAT/src/NEAT_GeneticIndividual.cpp
> =

> I am attaching it, but I don't know how that works with the yahoo 
group=
.
> 
> Crossover occurs in this constructor:
> 
>     
GeneticIndividual::G=
eneticIndividual(shared_ptr<GeneticIndividual>
> parent1,shared_ptr<Genetic=
Individual> parent2,bool 
mate_multipoint_avg)
> 
> The following line occu=
rs outside of the loop that goes through each 
link:
> 
>  bool chooseFirst=
Parent =3D (randomChoice<=3Dparent1->getFitness());
>  
> Then, inside the =
loop for each link:
> 
>                     if (chooseFirstParent)
>      =
               {
>                         addLink(GeneticLinkGene(*link1))=
;
>                     }
>                     else
>                     =
{
>                         addLink(GeneticLinkGene(*link2));
>            =
         }
>  
> So, it seems that *all* the links will be grabbed from one=
 parent or 
the
> other. Is that how it works in other versions of NEAT?
> =

> 
> 
> Cheers,
> Jeff Clune
> 
> Digital Evolution Lab, Michigan State Un=
iversity
> 
> jclune@...
> 
> 
> 
> 
> > From: petar_chervenski <petar_cher=
venski@...>
> > Reply-To: "neat@yahoogroups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.com>
> >=
 Date: Sun, 09 Nov 2008 20:14:32 -0000
> > To: "neat@yahoogroups.com" <neat=
@yahoogroups.com>
> > Subject: [neat] Re: Crossover doing anything in Hyper=
NEAT and 
PNEAT?
> > 
> > Hi Jeff, 
> > 
> > Well I don't know about the ex=
act implementations of HyperNEAT you 
are
> > using (note that P-NEAT is ju=
st NEAT with additive mutations
> > disabled), but in principle crossover s=
hould choose genes randomly
> > from both parents as it builds the offsprin=
g genome, the child. In
> > HyperNEAT the crossover is different, there you=
 actually do a 
regular
> > NEAT evolution of networks that build other net=
works based on the
> > substrate configuration. That is, you only mate and =
mutate the 
CPPNs.
> > But in the case you get lots of individuals with equ=
al fitness, I
> > guess these individuals are clones. Perhaps the code freq=
uently
> > chooses the same individuals for mating? You can try to avoid th=
is 
by
> > introducing a loop in which you try candidates for a "father" th=
at 
are
> > not compatible with the mother, that is, when their compatibili=
ty
> > distance is 0.00, try again. There is another possibility, simply
> =
> every mutation disturbs the CPPN and therefore the produced 
network is
>=
 > changed in such a magnitude that is has no chance for survival and 
is
>=
 > discarded. Even though there is speciation.
> > 
> > Peter
> > 
> > 
> >=
 --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune <jclune@> wrote:
> >> 
> >> Hello =
all-
> >> 
> >> Does crossover do anything in PNEAT and HyperNEAT?
> >> 
> =
>> PNEAT:
> >> If I am reading the code correctly, during crossover, if the=

> > substrates are
> >> the same (i.e. all links have the same ID), which =
is always the 
case
> > in
> >> P-NEAT, *all* of the link values are taken =
from either parent1 or
> > parent2.
> >> Isn't it more normal when crossing=
 over to take some from parent1
> > and some
> >> from parent2? Why grab al=
l from just one?
> >> 
> >> This means that in PNEAT crossover does nothing=
, right? It will
> > always grab
> >> the substrate of parent1 or the subst=
rate of parent2.  If I track
> > parent and
> >> offspring fitness, 100% of=
 the time the child has the exact same
> > fitness as
> >> one of the two p=
arents.
> >> 
> >> On to HyperNEAT:
> >> 
> >> I tracked the fitness of eac=
h parent and the resulting offspring.
> > The odd
> >> thing is that the or=
ganisms that are crossed only (i.e. they are
> > never
> >> mutated) have t=
he *exact* same fitness of one of their parents
> > 98.88% of the
> >> time=
. In 20 runs, that was only 136 orgs out of 12257 that were
> > crossed ove=
r
> >> and not mutated. That seems wrong, doesn't it? Why would these 
new
=
> > links
> >> have such a small impact? It turns out that this is because =

nearly
> > every
> >> time that there is an extra link that gets placed in=
 the child, 
the
> > parent
> >> that donated that link is also the parent =
whose weights are being
> > grabbed,
> >> meaning that the crossover is onl=
y copying the parent (hence the
> > same
> >> fitness). It seems to me that=
 crossover should be much more
> > disruptive, no?
> >> 
> >> 
> >> As a fi=
nal test, I did a set of hyperneat and pneat runs with the
> > default
> >>=
 'MutateOnlyProbability' parameter set to .25, so 25% of orgs 
never
> > ar=
e
> >> candidates for crossover. I then ran experimental treatments
> >> hy=
perneat-noCross and pneat-noCross where the 
MutateOnlyProbability
> >> par=
ameter was set to 1, so no orgs were crossed over. Despite my
> > comments
=
> >> above, Hyperneat (with cross) did beat HyperNEAT-noCross, however
> > =
the
> >> difference was not tremendous (although it does seem to be
> > sta=
tistically
> >> significant). For p-neat, the reverse was true. Nevertheles=
s, 
this
> > is not a
> >> perfect test of whether crossover pays dividends=
, because if
> > crossover does
> >> nothing most of the time, and I increa=
se MutateOnlyProbability 
from
> > .25 to
> >> 1, I have effectively raised=
 the mutation rate (only 80% of 
crossed
> > orgs are
> >> also mutated).
>=
 >> 
> >> Are these the intended consequences of crossover, or am I missing=

> > something?
> >> 
> >> Cheers,
> >> Jeff Clune
> >> 
> >> Digital Evolu=
tion Lab, Michigan State University
> >> 
> >> jclune@
> >> 
> > 
> > 
> >
